thread.title: Fans Go Wild for the Wild at AMSOIL
thread.title_full: Fans Go Wild for the Wild at AMSOIL

title: Fans Go Wild for the Wild at AMSOIL
text:
Fans Go Wild for the Wild at AMSOIL 
By Norman Seawright III September 30, 2015 Updated Sep 30, 2015 at 7:03 PM CDT 
Duluth, MN (NNCNOW.com) -- The Minnesota Wild wrapped up two days of practice at AMSOIL Arenaâ€”the preseason ice time gets the team season-ready, but it also put them in front of Northland fans for the day. 
"Duluth's great for the Wild, and the Wild are great for Duluth," said fan Marty Running. 
Click here to subscribe to our daily newsletter. 
Whether or not Wild faithful are willing to travel to St. Paul to watch the team play, they appreciate seeing their favorite men on skates. 
"You never really get to see professional athletes, especially outside the Minneapolis area," said fan Zack Ziegler. "It's kind of cool that they're down the street from us." 
It's always worth the trip, even if you have something else you could be doing. 
"I don't have class until [1:00 PM]," said Kami Oberaigner. 
Brittany Oberaigner, on the other hand: "I'm on a really long lunch." 
Some choose their favorite players for sentimental reasons. 
"Nino Niederreiter," said Shai Peterson. "We share the same birthday." 
Others... not so sentimental. 
"Parise," said Kaitlyn Wisocki (who attended practice on her birthday with her boyfriend). "Because he's really cute and he's from Minnesota!" 
Regardless, in the State of Hockey, fans stand behind their team no matter what. 
"I think we've got a really good shot to go to the playoffs," said Adam Orcutt. "It's been tough the last three years playing against Chicago, but hopefully we can beat them this year with the guys they lost." 
The players appreciate the crowd enthusiasm. 
"We never get to see fans up close like that, that often, so for that to happen today was neat," said Wild defenseman Ryan Suter. "The guys definitely appreciated it." 
"All the other cities besides Minneapolis and St. Paul love the Wild," said Wild forward Jason Pominville. "It's great to see them out here."
